review_title: Dysfunctional and lurching from crisis to crisis
pros: Good perks - free and cheap tickets to concerts, drinks in the office on Fridays. Highly multicultural and international, which makes the work often interesting.
cons:
Very long working hours (on email from 6am to 10pm, in office from 7.30am to 7pm, frequently later, on occasions until 3am). Resourcing gaps rarely filled - when half the team went on maternity leave, the rest of us were given double workloads as "stretching objectives" only to be passed over for bonuses and promotions. 

Poor management culture; decisions and progression based on who you know and are friends with rather than skill or experience. Management don't value subject matter expertise. Extremely low morale; many jobs were cut, others walked at the same time. People left are those who can't leave because of visas, or who simply can't get another job.

Frustratingly bad IT. Clunky old kit, limited access to any online tools that would make the job easier. Made a big song and dance about a new intranet but it seems the same as the old one only with more corporate banner ads. Takes days to get basic IT or HR problems fixed.

pros: This is an employee caring company and participate quite a number of public events.  It has also introduced some great idea and benefit and also favour to the city, like EV leave.
cons: I don't know why a bank in HK can have no annual for the staff to sit together and enjoy.  Eventhough earliers there is survey on whether colleagues want to retain annual dinners or not.  And the answer is not, but I think the "NOT" there means the staff do NOT want to spend too much time on the preparation rather than don't want it.

review_title: Work Life Balance is a myth in this place
pros: There are unlimited medical benefits, that's it.
cons: Long list there. The place is extremely inhuman and is saddled with so many processes that no person, no matter how efficient, can ever put up with all of them. The Team lead position is only meant to be there for moral support, and they still manage to be inefficient at that too. The Credit Analysts are expected to do any and everything. Really long work hours, expectations to work on all the weekends, complete lack of guidance for new joiners, the list will go on & on. Recent policy changes being introduced include tracking every single mistake you make and then treating at as an excuse to lower your rating. They have introduced Dashboards to keep track of employee performance which has made the whole place a huge rat race.

pros: Good Brand , Excellent work life balance
cons: Small Franchise are left completely dependent on regional giant due to which all the major positions are held by expat. Further with its focus in restrict in only limited area, very low growth rate unlike in major market. worth mentioning about its policy of too much group dependent policies avoiding the local rules and market dynamics leading to frustration for the sales staff. Its like asking to go in the battlement without bullet from the local market perspective. No clear career growth path and parameters.

review_title: Great bank going through tough times
pros: A truly global and diverse organisation. Opportunities to move countries and roles within the bank.  A lot of good, professional, genuine people.
cons: The bank is seeking a new identity and is going through painful transformation, though the direction of travel is not clear (or at least not clearly communincated).   The atmosphere has not been the best during the last 2-3 years: gloomy and stressed faces are more common than happy ones. Much more politics than before. Backstabbing , which was virtually non-exitent in this organisation, is  on the rise.

review_title: Good place to work, great opportunities in Wholesale banking but terrible career in Consumer Banking
job_title: International Graduate (Management Associate), Consumer Banking in Mumbai
pros:
Great work life balance
Averagely decent money
Great culture
Supportive Managers
Great brand recall
A strong bank, relatively untouched by Financial Crisis
Great place to start if you're working in Wholesale Banking
cons:
Pay the lowest as compared to other banks.
Terrible HR, absolutely lackadaisical to the needs of the business or career progression of employees.
Once you're inside, you have to fend for yourself. 
DO NOT JOIN CONSUMER BANKING, frustrated frontline, frustrated managers, Will keep telling you that you're overpaid 'cause you're an MBA.

pros: Work Life Balance & employee medical policy
cons: There is ZERO Job security. You can get a mail one fine day and you will be asked to leave the organization that very day. The HR here is a joke and the company is insensitive to its own employees. After working and committing oneself to the bank, they will not even blink before cutting you off. Worst bank to work if you want job security. Highly recommended to find something other than stanchart, that you can pursue for long term. Also, the management is absolutely stupid, they make decisions before thinking of the consequences. Too much hiring and frequent change of processes is one of the most common features of the bank. This is obviously later justified by laying off people and cost cutting.

pros:
You can get AVP role at 10yrs and VP role at 15 if you negotiate well as SCB needs smart people.
Once joined forget about promotion as you literally need to be managers pet  for getting it.
Existing employee base is technically very backward so good opportunities for techies to get good offers.
cons:
Till how long would you survive politics here on a day to day basis.
Hike is very bad now-a-days.. May God help you if you are coming with low intake.
Only escalation works
Everyone thinks they have to make strategy and execution has to be done by someone else as everyone is a manager here.

pros: Known international financial services brand
cons: Behind all the fancy slogans and brand name, SCB Kenya is a disgrace to the global brand and reputation of this financial services company. SCB encourages an extremely rude and demoralizing style of management especially in retail banking. Workplace bullying is commonplace.  Speak to the relationship managers and you will be told about repeated incidents and patterns of behavior intended to intimidate, offend, degrade or humiliate colleagues, all in the guise of bringing in clients and increasing "numbers'. It is an extremely unprofessional culture and a shame to SCB globally. Colleagues come to work and are demoralized because of the verbal abuse suffered at the hands of managers and heads of retail. This bank should be investigated.

pros: Am I newer to the team and so far things have been going well. I have found the team to be welcoming and engaging and that everyone here wants to contribute to the success of the business. The office culture is friendly and people enjoy working hard and having fun. I have been able to make an impact and provide input and suggestions even while still being new to the team. And my boss and the office culture in general support a positive work life balance.
cons: It isn't so much of a con, but you should be prepared to work closely with your peers in an open setting. If you can't thrive in that kind of situation then it could be more difficult for you.

review_title: Good work-life balance and friendly Bank
pros:
Work-life balance and flexi working, with the Bank offering many extra curricular benefits.
Good opportunities to move around the Bank.
Nice working environment and friendly place to work.
The holiday leave is very generous.
cons:
Many people take advantage of the flexi working and it can encourage people to drift along.  It therefore sometimes lacks the passion and drive of other Banks.
There is plenty of red tape and bureaucracy so decision take a long time and people are reluctant to take decisions.

review_title: Unstable with job cuts/low job security but friendly people and environment (2.5 stars)
pros: People are generally friendly and good environment. Interesting, fairly diverse and international and good work life balance and pto, good benefits
cons: Low job security and there are recent job cuts everywhere and constant restructurings affecting every department. Many contract employees and cost cuts/functions (and other signs) that show poor management and seemingly stagnant future. Not a major player so you kind of know what you're signing up for and get some work life balance but security issues make it lopsided in evaluating.  Consider this more seriously and honestly would probably only advise for someone in tight circumstances or maybe at entry level needing any kind of initial exposure. Pay is below market and 401K does not immediately vest. Potentially longer hours dealing with overseas.

review_title: The Cons outnumber the Pros, but the Pros outweigh the Cons. Barely. Difficult in NY. Better in other centers.
pros: Emerging markets focus is compelling and lucrative. Fiscally healthy. Weathered the recession quite well. Compensation can be very good depending on the position. Benefits package is excellent: $60/mo. employer contribution for transit, FSA, Comprehensive Medical/Dental, with domestic partner coverage, generous paid leave, 3 volunteer days/year, paid training, 4% 401(k) employer match, pension.
cons: Lost opportunity to capitalize on weakness of bigger banks during downturn. Limited growth potential in NY... advancement usually requires relocation to target markets (Asia, Africa, Middle East). Terrible trading/risk management systems. Strategy from senior management is muddled. IT investment is well below the market standard.

review_title: Amazing- if you are a director/Senior Management
pros: All over the world, so chance to move around .Superb Corporate & Wholesale Banking Division that is second to none, cash management is quite good too.  Probably the bank that is going to huge when Africa takes off one day as they are all over the place there. Private Banking division has rosy future.
cons: Anemic Retail banking division although big and powerful. No trading department, so product trades take ages esp in Wealth Management. Old fashioned managers that take forever to make decisions yet first to bail  out to greener pastures when something goes wrong and let the subordinates take the blame. If you are outsourced (e.g SCOPE india )- you are screwed. Takes forever to get a PC and business card.

review_title: Front line sales profiles in India -  Exploitation
pros: The marathon that you get to run for
cons:
This was my first sales job and happened to be my first job too. 
We were given no practical on the job training whatsoever. 
The front line sales force face a similar plight across India.  You will be thrown out on the streets to fetch your targets. 
And even if one is putting in hard work and not achieving his /her  target  he or she will be shouted at and humiliated in front of other team members. 
Management does not believe in giving feed back in person or private but in front of a many people as possible. 
The is absolutely no amount of motivation that the sales force gets from the management. 

I left on a bad note dissatisfied and unhappy.

pros:
When I worked at the bank, it is in its difficult period because of changing legal environment and financial crisis. However, I was able to learn a lot and gain practical experience.Great work life balance but minimum chance for advancement. 
Misalignment between departments causes friction between different groups.
cons: Should be more competitive. Has a very laid back culture, might not suit the wall-street type of people. Not too many crazy hours. Pays a lot less than its competitors.Great place to work, gave me an opportunity without much experience. I learned so much and made many friends while working with the bank.

pros: Work life balance, easy job, good pay and good benefit. A lots of trainings program and internal transfers opportunity.
cons: Top down management where the failure to make the strategy change. Much more is known about planning than doing, about strategy making than making strategy work. Senior management oftenly handled poorly and slow execution. Work for your network and relationship is how they value your performance hence your hardwork is not priority. Good people left and wrong people in.

review_title: A mixture of extremely good and sometimes not so good
pros:
- Great opportunity to learn and change roles
- People all over are willing to help in most situations
- Merit based in most cases
- Great environment and people
cons:
- Currently going through reorganization creating job insecurity amongst senior level managers
- In some places the culture is not the best. There is too much fear and blame game when things go wrong. 
- Midrange salary and never the highest paying
- can be bureaucratic sometimes

review_title: Avoid middle to back offices at all costs
pros: If you are incompetent and aiming for mediocrity at most, then join risk or finance functions.  You will never get fired.
cons: Worst corporate culture and conduct in middle and back offices, cascading all the way from the top. Sexual harassment occurs daily but it's always the victim who gets asked to leave - obviously fostering and encouraging inappropriate behavior

pros:
Good stable culture, diversity and inclusion.  
Good for career entry level experience.
Good health insurance coverage. 
Good maternity leave period.  👏👏👏
cons:
Regular staff reviews are subjective, not objective.  
Too much politics, nepotism and outright tribalism. 
With the new Kenya CEO it's a bumpy ride for Kenyan staff.
Nil work-life balance unless a higher band level. 
Remuneration not commensurate with work.
Nil perks for entry level managers- nil allowances. 
Very good at out-managing staff instead of mentoring and nurturing. 
Salary scales way below market medians and minimal or nil annual reviews upwards. 
Shifting goals from one priority to the other-becomes confusing for staff on what they need to focus on.

pros: Great place to learn and gain knew skills and tools, everything i heart at this company transferred to all the jobs I held thereafter. I joined the bank as an International Graduate "IG" and through this program I got to do many rotations in various departments to learn how banks work. The bank invested in me and others so much that we could not really repay in anyway or shape. I left Standard Chartered Ban k- Dubai almost 7 years ago but until today I remember how well i was treated and respected by all my peers and managers. Thank you for everything SCB
cons:
Slow to move on HR related requests.
Little ambiguity when it comes to International Graduate program path and the way it works

pros: Good office space and located in old chennai city which near harbour.
cons: employees are asked to work over time everyday without pay. They tell you 9:30 to 6:30 but you will be allowed to leave only after 7:30pm or 8pm. If it crosses mid of the month, we will be made to stay until 9:30 or 10pm. and during the last week of the month we will be working until late night 1 am or 2am. and then will be give 30 mins grace time to come to the office late next day, which is technically the same day.

pros: Well organized, well structured international big company. Able to learn what a well organized company doing especially the procedure and policy. Good business prospective in long run. Good place to learn good operational practice.
cons: Too big and over engineered the process. Because of the well distributed international working condition and extensive outsourcing, process becomes extremely important. However, it slows down the good working team's performance and becomes inflexible. Additionally, this big structure created a lot of manager grade staff who are lack of productive value adding into the work. Ends up with 10 manager process monitor 1 working staff.

review_title: Good opportunities for career development; a very 'political' environment
pros: Unlike other 1st tier banks, SCB doesn't put much of weight on you academic background.  For those who couldn't get into the major investment banks.  SCB is a good place to advance your career.  It is easier to switch your functionality from wholesale banking to sales & trading once you are in.
cons: performance not evaluated by the work done, but heavily from people's perception.  You've gotta keep networking with bosses of your own and from other dept. as well.

job_title: FX Financial Markets Operations Analyst in City of London, England
pros: Lots of opportunities for international travel and relocation. Multicultural atmosphere and emphasis on international working creates a tangible sense of vibrancy and dynamism. Full of smart, driven and genuinely nice people. Work/life balance is manageable, although may vary in other parts of the bank. Good benefits.
cons: Antiquated IT systems create a lot of admin. Appraisal scores sometimes obviously driven by the companies wish to control compensation – rather than a true reflection of performance.

review_title: Experience at company depends on team
pros:
Great benefits, Self management of approach and results, Rewards and awards for hard work - effort counts.
Best feature - if you have an amazing idea and a plan behind it, and if you can go to the executives directly (bypassing your boss if he's an idiot), then they will listen to you and support you.
cons: Your experience depends entirely on the Branch manager and Regional head - there were some great and terrible ones in the mix. But no one can take away your rewards or benefits.

review_title: Good for outsider but wait till you join.
pros: Good pay, depending on how desperate the hiring manager is. Easy to transfer between teams/functions, again, depending on how your line manager view of career advancement/growth.
cons: Extremely bureaucratic, too much politic. You can only climb up the ladder by boot-licking and sweet-talking. Good pay and grade to external hiring rather than offering to hardworking existing employees. Non-stop restructuring since Q4 last year and it is still on-going. Higher management can't seem to make up their mind.

job_title: Specialist Functions Management Trainee in Jakarta
pros: The benefits offered is better than any other banks in the area as far as I notice, working time as well is flexible not quite tight, since there is not obligatory for you to sign in your presence upon arrival and departure.
cons: The environment is really bad for development, there is very little opportunity given to the employee to develop. Only few with higher level get more chance to being developed. You would see the gap, which is quite obvious. Group policy is to tight, hence give no room for improvement.

review_title: Interesting place to work and not in a good way
pros: Very flexible working which is helpful to everyone across the board, not just parents. Working parents are valued  and their time is considered often in things which is very positive. Good food at a subsidised cost. Poor management but pro as there is little monitoring.
cons: Awful internal culture with lots of people seeming to do minimal things with heightened expectations. Poor/negative and unprofessional attitudes seem to be rewarded. Slow and painful on boarding - 6 weeks at minimum.

pros: There are no pros it’s only the brand name
cons: There is no work life balance here. Each one in the team is overburdened and is working minimum of 12-14 hrs in a day. One person does the work of three people in the team. The hard working ones always suffer as they don’t know how to do buttering and trust me they are tortured more. Internal politics and partial environment overall. If you don’t have a personal life and you are good at buttering people you can surely join the bank.

review_title: Was a great place to work at 5 years ago!
pros: Ok so the pro's - Very open culture, you can walk up to seniors easily and talk to them, share your ideas. Also the company wants to innovate and is very open to listening to and implementing new ideas. Depending upon the department and country that you are in, work life balance can be good or challenging.
cons:
Pay is not as per industry standard at least on the consumer banking side
Changes in management in the last few years have made it very cut throat and cold! Top management especially in india was very friendly and genuinely concerned about employees. Doesn't seem to be the case now. Keep it to work and thats all they want!

pros:
Providing you are aggressive and a political animal you will do well - opportunities will open up to you very quickly. 
Great development resources provided from international network support. 
Aggresive in wanting to be the best international bank in China. 
Room and support for creative solutions
cons:
You are left to fend for yourself, not a culture of offering proactive support to set you up for success. 
Weak culture in China as a result of quick rotating Snr. Mgt. and executive team being mainly non -Chinese - here on short term assignments.  
A focus on packaging & marketing vs quality solutions. (politics wins over integrity and quality)

review_title: Relaxed work culture. Good place for people, who does not have much expectations from life.
pros:
Good employee benefits.
Highest no. of branches within India, so an employee can move to a different location.
Good presence in Asia and hence offers mobility to Singapore and Hong kong.
Good HR policies.
cons:
A person tends to get laid back and lethargic, because of the slow work culture.
No focus on professional development and on knowledge improvement.
Promotion and salary hike is very slow.
Most of the front-line and sales staff are not very educated and are just normal graduates.
Technologically not advanced and lack of coordination between various departments.

review_title: Good Brand to start you career
pros:
Broad and deep hierarchy  
Cross functional opportunities to grow within . 
Historic  customer  franchise and widespread presence in India amongst MNCs 
Customer acceptance percentage is satisfactory
cons:
Lower median remuneration in lower and mid management levels 
Losing talents through high attrition in recent time .
Cost to revenue ratio is not healthy 
Losing market share in wealth and CASA

review_title: Start-up culture but large matrixed organization
pros:
Those identified as top performers are given lots of opportunity for upward and lateral mobility, which is good for people who prefer a general management (vs specialization) career track. 

Senior management in London and other regional headquarters seem to care about making things better. 

Values based organization which is open to giving back to the community.  Lots of opportunity for volunteerism.
cons:
Hard to navigate matrixed organisational structure - which often slows down decision making and results in lack of ownership (probably common with all large global companies?)

A lot of managers just focus on pleasing upper management, often ignoring or trying to cover up the real problems and issues. 

Majority of internal infrastructure outdated or not user friendly

review_title: Good for talented people but not organized
pros: Fast Paced Environment and they invest in talented employees. Promotions are fast and host a number of young aged talents.
cons: No Clear Strategy, Most training courses were on leadership but no technical skills training. Concentration of 1 or 2 nationalities on a regional level (which were cost-oriented and zero risk policy) that killed entire countries business. No work-life balance

review_title: What you do will be really different from what's written on their website and during recruiting.
pros:
Good employment benefits (15 days annual leave at least, vacation expense complementary)
No check-in and check-out, which is very different from the traditional local way.
cons:
The programme basically offers little on-job training and involves lots of time when you have to force sell people products. You will be doing what a salespeople do and that's the only thing you will be doing in this programme as well.

Also, there's a lack of team spirit among colleagues; this could be due to the fact that most of the colleagues you will be working with are sales people in a branch who receive constant pressure from the branch manager and working in a team wouldn't help them in expanding their business so they are not encouraged to cooperate with one another, but rather work alone.

review_title: Great People, Strong Senior Management - Mediocracy in Middle Management, Location Matters
pros:
Overall a good place to work - salary and benefits package are competitive
Generally, the people are good people - likeable, willing to work hard
Areas for growth if you own your own career - including short term assignments, travel, and exposure to senior management
Bank wants to do good things
cons:
Slow to change - Top Team (C-levels) want to change, workers want to change - middle management can stop the change (out of fear)
Still has a fear culture in certain pockets
Good people means sometimes mediocre workers just get shuffled around

pros: Teammates are pretty nice and not as much politics within the team.
cons: CA job itself - long work hours, bad allocation of tasks, no control on work load since RMs can throw any task at you and say it is urgent, forced to do very admin work because IT system too stupid to do the admin work - never seen anything as admin as this and i hve worked at other banks before, no support from management at all. We are all left to drown in impossible workload and deadline. It is not uncommon to work over weekends / work late.  Zero work life balance and highly stressed life with low salary - not worth it. People only focus on your mistakes and not your achievements which makes the whole work experience highly demoralizing. Most people leave within 2 years or less. Hard work is not appreciated.

job_title: Business Banking Relationship Manager in Hong Kong
pros:
Young and energetic culture to drive attachment (at the same time, it mean aggressive!)
It is a social responsible bank to offer products that react the tough market situation. Clients can survive during this coronavirus challenging time.
cons:
Long working hours and pressure on delivering result in the earliest stage (better as early as possible).
Too strict to obtain a score in a commission scheme. Its rules always are changed without communicating with frontline. Harder to be promoted now.

review_title: Its really good place to work
job_title: Senior Software Developer in Beijing, Beijing
pros: Don't thin that India is good place to work. I have been worked in China and It was cool place and good work culture and very supportive people.Technically you can learn lots here.
cons: Standards Charted in Bangalore very worst and If your talented then this is not your place. Initially  I have applied through career portal but no calls. And My resume almost match with any Banking domain but dont know really hiring process is going in Bangalore. Karma is B in India they rejected my resume N numbers but I got selected in China with help of my friends. So for talented people India is not place to work for IT Professionals.

pros: Good Company to learn about the banking industry.
cons: Depending on the country and location of the company, the culture varies from being very good and cooperative to downright bad. Politics is rampant and the main driving force in the company, especially the work life balance culture can be sometimes preposterous. Movement and promotion within company is very restricted and mainly depends on who you know and how you maintain your relationship with him/her. Some of the heads openly misbehave with its employees, and sometimes can call you in abnormal hour of the day even if you are sick or on leave.

review_title: Decent workplace - relationshi Manger Employee Banking
pros: on time salary , less pressure compared to other banks,good colleagues , U get a good brand name
cons: weak HR , No proper guidance for freshers, unrealistic targets,No culture, no professionalism, lots of internal politics , they will even call you on Saturdays to do jobs which are not a part of your job role, Higher level managers behave as if they are having sole proprietorship and they not at all bothered about HR policies

pros:
It offers a highly competitive environment you are left no choice but to be the best amongst the best.
Standard chartered puts each of their employees on a pedestal and ensures what the CEO says and how he says it is replicated all the way. You can hardly tell the difference between a Direct Sales Rep and a senior manager. All are sharp, confident and well rounded
cons: SCB is a high pressure environment such that even if you are unwell your mind cannot rest knowing people are working while you are on bed rest

review_title: Brand you see from the outside is not the same what you see from the inside !
pros: Big brand, good pay package
cons:
Old outdated systems & technology
Pathetic processes
You will survive and thrive if you are an "yes man"
Biased HR that doesn't have the wherewithal to question Biz Seniors since their ratings are provided by the business they support..in other words Puppets!
No Foolproof KPIs, Senior Management's decision on ratings & promotions are final
A bank of this size does Ratings and Increments on Excel and no standardized processes or policies...heavily dependent on the Senior Mgt's discretion

pros: The international graduates are given good exposure to top management and taken on loop with organizational level strategy and the way ahead. They are always in on the bigger picture of business due to frequent interactions with senior management. International graduate enter one grade higher than the starting grade (starting grade i.e. the lowest permanent employee level is G9, IG's enter at G8) and after the completion of 2 year program all IG's are promoted to the next grade (G7) together with permanent placement for which they get several options. There is a good amount of international mobility, both during the two year program and afterwards. Many IG's chose to work in a market different from their home countries upon completion of the program. The IG're are paid higher than the average employee on the same grade and well looked after generally during the program.
cons:
Once the IG program finishes, then its different for different people. Some find it hard and same as end of honeymoon period. Quite a lot of IG's leave the bank afterwards. A lot depends on where the graduates chose to work. Some markets are great and have good potential, others not so much.  Also the IG's are used to good support during the program from HR and afterwards its no so forthcoming anymore which is a rather disappointment. The HR policies for common employees are rather 'not pleasant' and the IG's once they become part of regular core of employees feel the heat more .
Apart from this the usual issue of long working hours and politicism and nepotism prevails in some markets atleast and its quite a downer for the younger lot.

job_title: Assistant Relationship Manager in Hong Kong
pros: International firm, that's all the Pro I can think of.
cons: Pretty much everything that you could think of, from the companies' structure, policies, to your colleagues and salary.  I am not a whiner but this is the impression I get after working for a year in this company.  I have worked in four different banks, overseas and Hong Kong and I have to say this company is by far the worst I have worked in.  Zero sense of belonging pretty much explains why the turnover rate is consistently high here, you are already considered to be a senior staff here if you have worked for two years as not a lot would make it over two years.

review_title: Massive Environment, but great for those who can handle a very "corporate" environment
pros: A dynamic workplace with a good customer and staff welfare ethos.  Lots of interesting projects and exciting opportunities for technical people.
cons: It is a massive organisation, so it is not for the feint hearted.  Adherence to policies and process is necessary to avoid chaos in such a large environment, so to succeed you have to respect the purpose of the policies and process, but not let them stifle you.

review_title: A place where you may realize your full potential.
pros: highly competitive and professional work place.. emphasis on employee training and development.. great organization to learn and enhance your skills and talents.. great on the job learning.. international exposure and expertise
cons: a bit of work place politics may annoy you

job_title: Regulatory Compliance Business Analyst in London, England
pros: As an international bank it is very multi-cultural and understands the different needs of global clients. It is community focused does a huge amount to support 'Seeing is Believing'.
cons: The recent switch  and changes to management structure and style is a issue as with many other companies, it makes for a lot of uncertainties and employees feel unappreciated for many years of service, career growth within is hard to come by as it seems who you are connected to is considered more than your ability to perform the role .

pros:
- Caring culture, active in community service
- Opportunity to work with colleagues around the world
cons:
- Unrealistic expectations for the amount of resources provided, which means long hours, tough to meet targets and in-fighting between teams to secure more resources
- Low levels of job security for junior staff. Management constantly cultivates a perception that you need to do more and that you are easily replacable 
- Reward and promotion is pretty much hit and miss, really depends if you have a line-manager that recognize your contributions (frequently not). In which case one needs to be aggressive enough to make their contributions known to management a level above which may upset your line-manager.

pros:
The level of exposure to international banking is amazing.
Though it thrives mostly on asian and african banking.
Movement across horizontals is something really helpful in this organisation. One of the very few places which keeps you safe at the time of global recession.
cons:
Very little opportunities in US/Europe, especially if you are working in the banking technology.
Plus this is a place quite reluctant to changes as per the market. Takes a lot of time to adopt the new  methodologies.

review_title: Good for entry level, not much else.
pros:
- PTO and Benefits
- Most people are nice and friendly
- Good place to learn the business primarily
cons: Too much nepotism and politics. If you’d like to advance in this company, better learn how to affix your lips to a posterior! There’s always an excuse for lack of advancement. Inept people somehow get all the promotions, and actual knowledgeable people stay at the bottom.

review_title: It has been a good learning experience, SCB India is a very employee-friendly place to work
pros: Supportive work culture, employee-friendly policies, strong presence in India gives opportunities to be involved in headline transactions. SCB India has been involved in some big ticket domestic and cross-border transactions. Wholesale Banking has grown tremendously since it was set up 12 years ago.
cons: The management training program, known as the IG Program, is currently a 2 year program. It seems too long a duration for a training program, as market conditions can change drastically in 2 years!

review_title: A good place to start your career
pros: Lots of trainings opportunities. The International Graduates program is good for new graduates as it offers not only comprehensive trainings but also almost unlimited job openings when you are deployed. As the bank is grounded in Asia, Africa, and Middle-East, you will have cross-country exposure such as collaborating with international colleagues and rotations in another country. It is also possible to move internally to other countries if you are capable and well-connected.
cons: The system and procedures are ever changing, which results in unnecessary inefficiency sometimes. The working hours could be long once in a while, but is honestly very acceptable compared to many other banks.

review_title: Conservative banking but good learning environment
pros:
Good learning environment
Structured organization (people are dispensable)
Open door policy
Some international opportunities
Talent recognition
Good culture overall
cons:
Lower than market compensation (unless you are your boss's favorite)
Conservative banking; not aggressive like other top banks and thus lacking behind big names
Big name in some geographies and completely non-existent in others (Thus not a well known name globally)
HR's performance is not as good as other departments; lags behind in many ways!

review_title: amazing footprint but many legacy issues
pros: The bank has an amazing footprint.  If you want to work for a truly global, emerging market institution that can give you exposure to EM + Frontier, this is it.  They have deep history in many of these far-flung places and I would think they will never leave.  This gives a deeply embedded advantage over other international players and, of course, local competition.  I actually feel "here for good" is an excellent representation of this and a wonderful tagline for the company.  Long history, through it all, thick and thin.  If you stand in Central in HK and look at HSBC and SC buildings side by side (notwithstanding that SC sold its building a long time ago) you see what I mean - HSBC purportedly built its building to be modular so they could dismantle it and ship it out after the handover in '97 if things got hairy.  Who knows if this is true or not but the building looks the part.  SC building is a veritable fortress by comparison - in other words, "here for good" in living color.
cons: The bank has an absolutely toxic culture.  There has been far too much change at all levels of management.  New management come in, excited by all the aforementioned pros and have unreasonable expectations heaped on them and they simply cannot deliver.  The result is they fire their directs or themselves get fired (as the blame goes around) and the cycle repeats itself.  The bank has to figure out a way to break this cycle.  The people that have been around for more than 2 years are inevitably those that are best place to avoid getting caught by this - have either managed to fire and apportion blame or have avoided decisions or rose through the ranks quickly.  It's sadly apparent throughout the organization.  The functions are mediocre to incompetent and don't know how to support front office.  The middle and front of offices are working off of antiquated systems - there has been no investment in improving systems, majority of investment is on regs.  The conundrum faced by the institution is that so many areas of the bank need to be literally burnt down and rebuilt, but the cost to do so is so great, that it is simply not possible from the highest stakeholders (shareholders, board) on down.  Senior management rolled out a campaign recently, presumably to fulfill it's obligation to "change the culture" called "Our Shared Values."  In some ways it is good and necessary but in others it is a sad reflection on the state of the bank.  For instance, value #1 is "do the right thing."  In my opinion, anyone that is not clear on or doesn't automatically know to do the right thing shouldn't be at the bank to begin with.  So does this mean the bank tolerates employees or managers or don't spell out or do the right thing?  It's very confusing and illustrates the challenging place that the bank is in.

pros: The country teams are great - the environment in country is friendly, my own team is very supportive, flexibility allowed i.e. work from home, in country management is considerate, maternity leave is great, etc. The pay is good, learning opportunity is good up to a certain extent.
cons:
Unspoken corporate hierarchy/politics where your behavior is shaped based on the seniority of who you are addressing - one of the worst I’ve experienced though they advertise it as otherwise.

Blame game is big - focus should be “we found a problem what’s the solution” instead this ends up being a blame game instilling negativity and at times even fear.

Constant structural changes by higher management - and I mean constant with no clear rational or vision communicated to employees on ground facing these changes full face. These changes are sometimes blanket changes and seem like the are no considerations for particular regions/ countries. 

You spend a lot of time doing irrelevant work this may be due to being an international bank adhering to many international regulations but sometimes you feel you can drown in doing documentation work. A large part of this is because the bank supports “simplifying” this is not actually done. The bank invests heavily on software, etc to make the client experience smoother however internally there is much to do to simplify - there are so many systems created that do not speak to each other. Many times we have to deal with large data where we spend hours trying to clean it up as a result . Processes at times are slow because of so many unnecessary systems not speaking to each other and so many work flow layers - think of an assembly line for a factory each line assembling one thing (literally). Sometimes software and systems should be created to ease particular work - this is not done to the extent that you think that your stuck in the 90s with the way these processes has not yet been updated.

The big clients are everything and if you do one tiny mistake like not respond to them even if it’s way past working hours your questioned by everyone internally surprisingly the internal team will give you a harder time than the actual client itself. God forbid you make an error.



Some people at work need to learn communication skills.

Although I say that SCB encourages work life balance I have to add this does not apply to everyone - unfortunately some teams work constantly even on weekends and late into the night i.e. I do receive emails from those at 3 AM in the morning their time. And when asked they explain that they are under pressure and have lots of work to do. 

Many talented people were given the cut, this brings into an underlying question on job security always.

This is for maybe the bank management - management encourages speak up for all things and try to normalized it - however speak up to employees is the highest form of escalation and not very available option. Fear, worry, being questioned etc is always on the table.

A lot of teams frequently change and this change brings about inconsistency and confusion - i.e. every time this team changes they change along with it the way things are done e.g. team one prefers a, b and c. Team two comes and say go back
To 3,21 - then team 3 comes back and says no we should do a,b,c again.

Business team is the all knowing God for every known thing even the most irrelevant to them in the bank for some reason. They are like an octopus with arms extending everywhere and at the same time are definitely not empowered on relevant decisions because they are the con man for lack of better terminology.
